Subject: Accounting
ParentText: Business and Economics - Accounting

Subject: Accounting
ExampleText: Unit 1 The role of accounting in business

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Outcome 1:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Describe the resources required to establish and operate a business, and select and use accounting reports and other information to discuss the success or otherwise of the business.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Examples of learning activities

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Case studies: Using case studies of businesses where accounting has played a pivotal role in decision-making, financial management, and business success, analyse how accounting principles were applied in different scenarios.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Guest speaker: Listen to an invited professional accountant, financial manager, or local business owner speaking to the class. Ask them to share their real-world insight into the accounting functions within a business and provide examples of the importance of accounting.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Role-playing: Working in groups allocate each student a role within a group in a fictious business (e.g. owner, accountant, manager), then simulate scenarios that involve interacting and making decisions based on financial information.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Financial statements analysis: Analyse financial statements from a company (e.g. balance sheet, income statement, cash flow statement). Discuss how each statement reflects the financial health and performance of the business.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Interactive online modules: Using interactive online modules or tutorials that simulate business situations, make accounting-related decisions. Platforms such as Coursera, Khan Academy, or educational software specifically designed for accounting are all useful.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Industry research: Use teacher-assigned industries for research. Choose industries where accounting practices differ significantly (e.g. retail vs. manufacturing). Present findings on how accounting practices vary based on industry-specific needs and regulations.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Excursions or virtual tours: Visit a business in the local community to observe first-hand how accounting systems are implemented and used in real-world settings.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Conduct research on the ownership structure of a range of businesses. Describe the ownership structure of each one and explain the advantages and disadvantages of each structure identified.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Prepare a visual representation depicting the accounting equation and the accounting elements it is comprised of (assets, liabilities, owner's equity, revenues and expenses).

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Select a business that has decided to make itself more environmentally, socially or ethically responsible. Examples include: adopting a method to recycle resources, reducing packaging, adopting the Fairtrade model or using only socially responsible suppliers. Research and critically analyse the impact of this decision on the business; i.e. on its reputation and financial performance. This activity could be done via an interview with a small business owner or by listening to a guest speaker address the class.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Interview an accountant, a business advisor or a representative of a professional association. Prepare a presentation about the role of an accountant or financial advisor in a business enterprise.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Interview a business owner and discuss and determine the factors they consider when setting prices. Identify any ethical considerations involved in setting prices.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Calculate a range of prices using different price-setting methods, such as recommended retail price, mark up and cost- volume- profit analysis

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Calculate the breakeven point for a product, and then explain the impact that a change in a range of fixed and variable costs could have on the final selling price. For example, how might switching to recyclable packaging, sourcing key ingredients from sustainable sources, and changing to fixed costs (such as rent) affect the final price?

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Discuss the topic of ethical considerations when making decisions in relation to operating a business.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Visit a business in the local community

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Identify suitable local businesses:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Research small businesses in your area that might be willing to accommodate student visits. Ideally, choose a business that connects with students' interests. Possibilities might include:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Beautician
ParentText: Research small businesses in your area that might be willing to accommodate student visits. Ideally, choose a business that connects with students' interests. Possibilities might include:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Photographer
ParentText: Research small businesses in your area that might be willing to accommodate student visits. Ideally, choose a business that connects with students' interests. Possibilities might include:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Giftware shop
ParentText: Research small businesses in your area that might be willing to accommodate student visits. Ideally, choose a business that connects with students' interests. Possibilities might include:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Health food shop
ParentText: Research small businesses in your area that might be willing to accommodate student visits. Ideally, choose a business that connects with students' interests. Possibilities might include:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Fitness or personal training.
ParentText: Research small businesses in your area that might be willing to accommodate student visits. Ideally, choose a business that connects with students' interests. Possibilities might include:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Contact the business:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Reach out to the selected businesses via phone, email, or in person. Explain the purpose of the visit, the age group of the students, and the topics they are learning about in VCE Accounting. Ask if they are willing to host students for a visit.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Plan the visit date and time:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Liaise with the business to schedule a date and time for the visit that works for both parties. Ensure it aligns with the students' school schedule. Organise transport if required. Complete the excursion paperwork.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Develop an itinerary:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Create a detailed itinerary for the visit, including activities the students will engage in and the topics that will be covered. Consider including a tour of the business premises, presentations by staff members about their roles and how accounting is used in their day-to-day operations, and Q&A sessions.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Prepare students:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Brief students about the purpose of the visit, the expectations for their behaviour, and discuss specific questions they may want to ask during the visit. Encourage them to research the business and prepare thoughtful inquiries.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Explain the assessment task connected to this excursion:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Folio or digital presentation explaining what they have learned covering the key knowledge points of Outcome 1.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Follow-up:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: After the excursion, debrief with students, discussing what they learned and any insights gained about accounting in small businesses.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: Students who are absent on the day of the excursion can research a business for their digital presentation assessment.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The role of accounting
ExampleText: To assess the students' digital presentation covering the specified topics, create a rubric with criteria aligned with the key learning objectives. See below.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Outcome 2:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Identify and record financial data, report and explain accounting information for a service business, and suggest and apply appropriate financial and non-financial indicators to measure business performance.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Examples of learning activities

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Complete a folio of Journal entry practice.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Use interactive games (AI or group) such as Zapitalism.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Role-play scenarios where accounting is used; for example, use the game 'Monopoly' to record cash in a folio.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: In groups, complete projects to compile financial data, prepare financial statements, and create a presentation to explain the financial performance of a chosen company. This collaborative activity reinforces an understanding of accounting principles.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Collect a range of documents used by a business to record financial transactions. Examine these, identify, describe and analyse the key data contained in each.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Record a range of financial transactions in the cash and credit journals for a business.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Describe the two-fold effect of a range of financial transactions.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Using a spreadsheet, record transactions in journals and prepare financial reports.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Design and run a small service business (as a class activity). Record transactions, manage supplies and then evaluate business performance.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Create and maintain a glossary of appropriate accounting terms. Include the accounting assumptions, qualitative characteristics and types of documents used to record financial transactions by a business. This could be displayed prominently in the classroom.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Use a spreadsheet representing an Income Statement to model the effects of various business decisions on the accounting equation. Construct appropriate graphical representations of the data. Provide advice to the business owner about how the business is performing and areas of potential improvement.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Complete a series of exercises using financial and non-financial data and indicators of business performance to evaluate business performance.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Use a spreadsheet to prepare a cash flow statement and prepare appropriate graphs depicting indicators of business performance using data from the cash flow statement.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Using the data provided in a spreadsheet for two businesses, design and prepare appropriate graphs. Compare the performance of the two businesses.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Prepare a YouTube information clip about the Goods and Services Tax (GST). Explain what it is, how it works and how it is recorded within a business' financial records.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Use a spreadsheet to model how different strategies to improve business profitability might work. This should be based on a business scenario.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Using provided financial reports, evaluate the performance of a business and provide appropriate advice to the business owner.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Use a case study to discuss the internal control procedures used to safeguard resources against theft and fraud. Discuss the ethical considerations a business owner should take into account when recording transactions.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Discuss the ethical considerations faced by business owners when recording and reporting transactions.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Role-play and folio completion using 'Monopoly'

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Get game - board game or interactive version - and place the board on a table with groups of up to 8 people.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Supply journal templates for Cash Receipt Journal and Cash Payments journal (link to template page).

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Players choose game pieces and start with a set amount of money - 500, 50; 6 each of 10, 1).

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Roll dice to move around the board.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Land on unowned property to buy it or auction it.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Pay rent when landing on opponent-owned properties.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Collect rent when opponents land on your properties.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Build houses and hotels to increase rent.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Jail: Go directly to jail, do not pass Go, do not collect $200, unless you roll doubles or use a "Get Out of Jail Free" card.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Chance and Community Chest cards provide opportunities or setbacks.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Income Tax and Luxury Tax are paid when landing on specific spaces.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Bankruptcy occurs when a player cannot afford to pay debts or expenses.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: The last player remaining after bankrupting opponents wins the game.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Record all cash purchases in the Cash Payments Journal.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Record all cash received in the Cash Receipts Journal

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Allow 20-30 minutes of game time in each class.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Allow 10-15 minutes at the end of each class to total the two journals:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Pretend each class is a week or month reporting period with the teacher guiding the dates changes throughout the class.
ParentText: Allow 10-15 minutes at the end of each class to total the two journals:

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: At the end of each class, students must have the following:

ExampleText: Completed Cash Payments Journal and Cash Receipts Journal including the totals
ParentText: At the end of each class, students must have the following:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Summary calculation of cash at bank in readiness for the next session
ParentText: At the end of each class, students must have the following:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Cash at start + CRJ - CPJ
ParentText: At the end of each class, students must have the following:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Include this detail as part of the folio to be submitted: handwritten, excel templates, online through the school's intranet or digital suite.
ParentText: At the end of each class, students must have the following:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Repeat for 1-2 weeks of classes (approximately 200-300 minutes).

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: Final class submission of folio:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Recording financial data and reporting accounting information for a service business
ExampleText: 3-5 Cash Receipt and Cash Payment Journals
ParentText: Final class submission of folio:

ExampleText: 3-5 summaries of cash balance.
ParentText: Final class submission of folio:

Subject: Accounting
ExampleText: Unit 2: Accounting and decision-making for a trading business

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Accounting for and managing inventory
ExampleText: Outcome 1:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Accounting for and managing inventory
ExampleText: Record and report for inventory and discuss the effects of relevant financial and non-financial factors, and ethical considerations, on the results of business decisions.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Accounting for and managing inventory
ExampleText: Examples of learning activities

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Accounting for and managing inventory
ExampleText: Simulation (an introductory activity): Using rewards (e.g. small lollies), work through a series of structured tasks designed to unpack terminology such as Inventory, Cost of Sales, Gross Profit, Inventory Loss/Inventory Gain.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Accounting for and managing inventory
ExampleText: Case studies: Examine case studies of selected businesses to learn how they do some or all of the following: recording and managing inventory, setting of re-order points, selection of suppliers, monitoring for fast- and slow-moving lines, tracking and reduction of inventory loss, storing and rotation of inventory, management of ethical issues. (Examples of suitable businesses include: IKEA, Lego (the toys that made us), Costco, JB HiFi.)

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Accounting for and managing inventory
ExampleText: Modelling: Model the impact on costings and/or financial reports of different options, providing recommendations and advice; for example: consider whether to purchase inventory of different quality standards or from different locations; consider whether to purchase licensed inventory, create a new product line or use a different supplier; consider the costing of different options to improve inventory turnover.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Accounting for and managing inventory
ExampleText: Inventory card investigation: In order to develop a working knowledge of all aspects of accounting and to understand the links between inventory and other areas of the study, practise recording into an inventory card, as well as extracting and deciphering information. Use teacher-provided completed inventory cards and extract key information such as: Cash Sales, Credit Sales, Cost of Sales. Provide a written description of a transaction on a particular date and prepare inventory cards, an Income Statement as well as any relevant additional information.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Accounting for and managing inventory
ExampleText: Complete a task related to a fictitious business that takes you through each stage of the recording and reporting process in order to develop an understanding of how financial data moves through the accounting system to ultimately inform decision-making.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Accounting for and managing inventory
ExampleText: Financial statement analysis: Use financial statements (e.g. balance sheet, income statement, cash flow statement) of a business. Discuss how each statement reflects the financial health and performance of the business and consider what could be done to improve inventory management and, therefore, the overall performance of the business.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Accounting for and managing inventory
ExampleText: Graphical representations: Use a teacher-provided graph depicting inventory turnover for a fictitious or real business and analyse the results, suggesting strategies for improvement. Note that with inventory turnover, higher change/trend is actually slower and a worsening of the outcome.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Accounting for and managing inventory
ExampleText: Guest speaker: Listen to an invited professional accountant, financial manager or local business owner speaking to the class (either in person or online). Ask them to share real-world examples and insights into how inventory is managed within a real business.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Accounting for and managing inventory
ExampleText: Interactive online games: Use Tycoon-based games (such as Lemonade Tycoon) to experience a business simulation involving decision-making that directly impacts business growth and performance. Teachers should check with the school's digital technology team to ensure students can access this at school.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Accounting for and managing inventory
ExampleText: Excursions or virtual tours: Visit a business in the local community to observe first-hand how accounting systems are used in real-world settings.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Accounting for and managing inventory
ExampleText: Simulation Task - Tracking Inventory

ExampleText: Background information:

ExampleText: Yash owns a toy warehouse in Keilor Downs. He sells a wide range of the latest toys and games. He is hoping that his business will see a big increase in sales over the next few weeks when a new toy-related movie will be released. In anticipation of this, Yash has purchased the full range of movie-related toys.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Accounting for and managing accounts receivable and accounts payable
ExampleText: Outcome 2:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Accounting for and managing accounts receivable and accounts payable
ExampleText: Record and report for accounts receivable and accounts payable, and analyse and discuss the effects of relevant decisions, including the influence of ethical considerations, on the performance of the business.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Accounting for and managing accounts receivable and accounts payable
ExampleText: Examples of learning activities

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Accounting for and managing accounts receivable and accounts payable
ExampleText: Case studies: Examine different businesses as case studies, look specifically at provide examples of how each does some or all of the following: recording and management of accounts receivable and accounts payable, decisions about whether to offer credit, the following up of accounts receivable, management of ethical issues. Note that publicly available case studies often focus on large-scale businesses with a variety of ownership structures; however, smaller businesses and sole proprietors are possibly more suitable for this activity

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Accounting for and managing accounts receivable and accounts payable
ExampleText: Modelling: Model the impact on costings and/or financial reports of different options; then provide recommendations and advice. Examples include: consideration of the purchase of supplies whether of different quality levels or from different locations or suppliers; assessment of the social and environmental effects of different models or options; decisions about how credit might be offered and to whom. Modelling options to replace ageing assets or move to a different option; for example: should the business replace a delivery van or should they use a delivery company? Should they buy a warehouse and move their business online or keep the shop they own?

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Accounting for and managing accounts receivable and accounts payable
ExampleText: Consider the cash cycle: Complete a task following the cash cycle of a business to develop an understanding of how inventory turnover, accounts receivable turnover and accounts payable turnover all impact the cash flow of a business.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Accounting for and managing accounts receivable and accounts payable
ExampleText: Financial statement analysis: Examine financial statements (e.g. balance sheet, income statement, cash flow statement) from a fictitious or real business. Discuss how each statement reflects the financial health and performance of the business. Then consider what could be done to improve either the accounts receivable or accounts payable management and, therefore, the overall performance of the business.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Accounting for and managing accounts receivable and accounts payable
ExampleText: Graphical representations: Unpack a graphical representation for items such as accounts receivable turnover, accounts payable turnover, credit sales.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Accounting for and managing accounts receivable and accounts payable
ExampleText: Revision task: Use teacher-provided pieces of paper that represent the key elements of financial reports, reconstructing them into two reports: an Income Statement and a Balance Sheet.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Accounting for and managing accounts receivable and accounts payable
ExampleText: Guest speaker: Listen to an invited professional accountant, financial manager or local business owner (even the school business manager) speaking to the class (either in person or online). Ask them to share real-world examples and insight into how accounts receivable and accounts payable are managed within a real busines

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Accounting for and managing non-current assets
ExampleText: Outcome 3:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Accounting for and managing non-current assets
ExampleText: Record and report for non-current assets and depreciation.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Accounting for and managing non-current assets
ExampleText: Examples of learning activities

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Accounting for and managing non-current assets
ExampleText: Case studies: Examine teacher-provided case studies of businesses with examples of how they conduct the following: record and manage non-current assets, predict useful life and residual value, track and minimise asset loss, maintain non-current assets over time and plan for their replacement, investigate and manage ethical issues.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Accounting for and managing non-current assets
ExampleText: Modelling: Model the impact on costings and/or financial reports of different options and then provide recommendations and advice. This might include consideration regarding purchase of non-current assets of different quality standards or from different locations or suppliers, consideration of the social and environmental impacts of different models/options. Also, the valuation of non-current assets and the financing of their replacements. Model options to replace ageing assets or move to a different option; for example, should a business replace a delivery van or should they use a delivery company? Should they buy a warehouse and move their business online or keep the shop they own?

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Accounting for and managing non-current assets
ExampleText: Accounting for non current assets: Complete the worksheet, including the worked example below in class. (Detailed example 1)

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Accounting for and managing non-current assets
ExampleText: Work through each stage of the recording and reporting process to demonstrate how financial data moves through the accounting system and ultimately informs decision-making.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Accounting for and managing non-current assets
ExampleText: Financial statement analysis: Using teacher-provided financial statements (e.g. balance sheet, income statement, cash flow statement) from a fictitious business, discuss how each statement reflects the financial health and performance of a business. Then, consider what might be done to improve non-current asset management and therefore overall business performance.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Accounting for and managing non-current assets
ExampleText: Graphical representations: Unpack a graphical representation of depreciation over time and label key points and other relevant items.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Accounting for and managing non-current assets
ExampleText: Guest Speaker: Invite a professional accountant, financial manager or local business owner to speak to the class (either in person or online). Ask them to share real-world examples and insights into how non-current assets are managed within a real business.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Accounting for and managing non-current assets
ExampleText: Excursions or virtual tours: Visit a business in the local community and observe / note the different types of non-current assets the business has. Discuss how the business maintains these, and then measure the contribution of each non-current asset to the revenue capacity of the business.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Extension of recording and reporting
ExampleText: Outcome 1:

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Extension of recording and reporting
ExampleText: Record financial data and balance day adjustments using a double entry system, report accounting information using an accrual-based system, and evaluate the effects of balance day adjustments and alternative methods of depreciation on accounting reports.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Extension of recording and reporting
ExampleText: Examples of learning activities

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Extension of recording and reporting
ExampleText: Using ICT, complete a survey including questions such as: If you have a part-time job when do you work and when do you get paid? When did the most recent electricity bill arrive at your home? Questions could also relate to car insurance and registration, as well as prepaid expenses, for example for mobile phones. After completing the survey, use the information gained to generate a discussion around cash versus profit, accrued wages and accrued expenses.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Extension of recording and reporting
ExampleText: Discuss financial decisions made when recording financial data and balance day adjustments, as well as reporting accounting information using an accrual-based system. Construct a mind map evaluating the ethical implications of these financial decisions.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Extension of recording and reporting
ExampleText: Brainstorm ideas before designing a poster highlighting the different types of non-financial information that could be used in business decision-making.

Subject: Accounting
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Extension of recording and reporting
ExampleText: Using the internet, identify an asset that a business might purchase, including its delivery costs. Then prepare a spreadsheet to model the impacts of depreciation of the asset on the Income Statement and Balance Sheet of the business.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Extension of recording and reporting
ExampleText: Discuss the impact of selecting a method of depreciation on the performance of a business over the life of the non-current asset.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Extension of recording and reporting
ExampleText: Complete a Kahoot or other form of online quiz relating to determination of the cost price of a non-depreciable asset and balance day adjustments.

ExampleText: Record financial data into General Journal and General Ledger

ExampleText: Discuss the ethical considerations for a business owner, with a focus on particular financial indicators. For example, a focus on Return on Investment could result in a higher risk if the owner is using debt to improve this indicator. Improving the net profit margin could result in job losses.

The titles can be written on Post-it notes or laminated strips so they can be easily moved about.
